newsitem.title: USA: B.A.T CEO proves influential in talks-WSJ.
newsitem.headline: B.A.T CEO proves influential in talks-WSJ.

text.p: Two of the U.S. tobacco industry's largest cigarette makers were ready to accept a broad regulatory power over nicotine but backed off at the urgings of B.A.T Industries Plc Chief Executive Martin Broughton, the Wall Street Journal said.
In Tuesday's electronic edition, the Journal said Broughton told his counterparts at Philip Morris Cos Inc and RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp they were giving up too much in settlement talks.

In particular, he urged the two companies not to back off their push to receive immunity from punitive damages. The Journal said those two companies were ready to present a settlement package to the White House that left unresolved the issue of punitive damages.
Unnamed sources told the Journal that industry negotiators had expected that Broughton, in meetings Friday with other executives, would merely say his piece and then fall into line.

Instead, during the seven-hour meeting, Broughton apparently stiffened the resolve of his U.S. counterparts, helping to convince Philip Morris and RJR not to give in on the punitive-damages issue, unnamed negotiators said.
B.A.T owns No. 3 U.S. cigarette maker Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp.
